pullRequest.title: SONARJAVA-3468 FP on S1905 when casted argument is an ambiguous method reference

beforeCommit.message: Remove odd checks from non compiling file, add false negative in tests

afterCommit.message: Remove odd checks from non compiling file, add false negative in tests

beforeCommit.message: Remove odd checks from non compiling file, add false negative in tests

afterCommit.message: Remove odd checks from non compiling file, add false negative in tests

nodes.bodyText: I agree that I can not think of a situation where it will be false, but I think we can let it for defensive programming.
This cast is not safe if we call this method with any TypeCastTree or if twoexpression() calls return different values. (it is not the case, but I still think it's good practice to not rely on it).
I would rather put this code in the non-compiling part.

This code:
bar(((Supplier<String>) Overloaded::fff));

will throw a ClassCastException here.
Using parent() is always annoying, there are many ways to write code to trick the rule. In doubt, I use defensive programming and accept if the coverage is not 100%.
Any reason why you used an early return here, instead of including this logic into the returned boolean expression?

foo((Supplier<String>) Overloaded::unknown); 

When the method reference is unknown, this code will throw a ClassCastException.

unknown((Supplier<String>) Overloaded::fff);

This code... does not raise a ClassCastException. :)
But an issue is still reported and I think it makes sense to not report an issue if we don't know the type expected. If the fix is easy, and it makes sense to include it with this PR, we could do it now.
Otherwise, we can simply create a new ticket to track this minor issue.

commit.message: Move test files to the proper test sources directory
Remove odd checks from non compiling file, add false negative in tests

nodes.bodyText: All this code is compiling and is duplicated in the compiling file. I think we should keep only what is not compiling in this file, to avoid duplication.

As a general observation, I tend to prefer to create an intermediate variable to store typeCastTree.expression().
In my opinion, it increases the clarity of the code and avoids problems in case it returns differents values between two calls, or if the computation is expensive.
Same for parentTree.parent(), to avoid having to call skipParentheses() twice.
Same here, let's create a variable to store symbol.owner().
I would also put this test in the compiling part, to be sure that unknown method does not prevent the Exception to happen.
